claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

rejected_evidence.quote: Egg based and cell culture based vaccines differ in the substrate in which reference vaccine viruses supplied to the manufacturer are propagated in quantities sufficient to produce the needed number of doses of vaccine. For the IIV4 s Afluria Quadrivalent (43), Fluarix Quadrivalent (123), FluLaval Quadrivalent (124) and Fluzone Quadrivalent (44), reference vaccine viruses are propagated in eggs. For Flucelvax Quadrivalent, reference vaccine viruses are propagated in Madin-Darby canine kidney cells instead of eggs (125).
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This quote establishes that both egg-based and cell-based flu vaccines use biological substrates (eggs or cell cultures) to propagate vaccine viruses, which is the process during which mutations can occur.

rejected_evidence.quote: The effectiveness of influenza vaccination varies depending on several factors, such as the age and health of the recipient; the type of vaccine administered; the types, subtypes (for influenza A), and lineages (for influenza B) of circulating influenza viruses; and the degree of similarity between circulating viruses and those included in the vaccine (12).
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This quote directly links vaccine effectiveness to the similarity between circulating viruses and those included in the vaccine, implying that any changes (such as mutations during production) that reduce this similarity could reduce effectiveness.

rejected_evidence.quote: Part attributable to bias, unmeasured confounding, or the late season emergence of antigenic drift variants of influenza viruses that are less well matched to the vaccine viruses.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This quote notes that the emergence of antigenic drift variants (mutations) can result in a mismatch between vaccine and circulating viruses, which can reduce vaccine effectiveness. While it does not specify production, it supports the principle that mutations can impact effectiveness.

rejected_evidence.quote: For persons who report a history of egg allergy, ACIP recommends the following: ... Most available influenza vaccines, with the exceptions of RIV4 (Flublok Quadrivalent, licensed for those aged ≥18 years) and ccIIV4 (Flucelvax Quadrivalent, licensed for those aged ≥6 months), are prepared by propagation of virus in embryonated eggs and might contain trace amounts of egg proteins, such as ovalbumin.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This quote confirms that most influenza vaccines are produced by propagating virus in eggs, a process known to allow for the development of mutations that can affect the vaccine virus.
